Instrument_Host.name: MICROROVER FLIGHT EXPERIMENT
Instrument_Host.description: The Microrover Flight Experiment (MFEX), also known as the Mars Pathfinder Rover or Sojourner, was a NASA mission aimed at exploring autonomous mobile vehicle technologies on Mars. Delivered with the Mars Pathfinder Lander on July 4, 1997, it conducted technology experiments over an extended mission timeframe, focusing on wheel-soil interactions, autonomous navigation, and hazard avoidance. The microrover featured a six-wheeled rocker bogie design allowing it to traverse obstacles and had a top speed of 0.4 m/min. Its mechanical components were protected from extreme Martian temperatures in a warm electronics box. Control was managed by an 80C85 computer using various sensors for navigation and obstacle avoidance. It was powered by solar panels and backup batteries, providing adequate energy for its operations. Communication with Earth was facilitated via a UHF modem system. The mission also included imaging the terrain to assist in navigating and goal setting.
